With regard to direct taxes, the modalities of the advance tax payments and payment deadlines will be adapted for corporations and self-employed persons. More specifically, legal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020 (due in March and June 2020). Covered by this measure are (corporate) income and municipal business taxes.    In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months. On this deferral, no interest on late payment will be due and it covers (corporate) income, municipal business, and net wealth taxes.  https://mfin.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B17-mesures-fiscales-covid19.html

Previous coding: 0  New coding: 1G    Health measures include wearing of masks, social distancing, frequent hand washing. Also distribution of masks, disinfectants, transparent barriers, and other hygiene measures by the government / ministry of education.  https://archive.vn/iLwYD  http://web.archive.org/web/20201006122016/https://men.public.lu/fr/actualites/communiques-conference-presse/2020/09/25-dispositif-cas-isole.html    Schools are closed for the summer holidays which started “on Thursday 16 July 2020 and end on Monday 14 September 2020”. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823230049/https://guichet.public.lu/en/outils/calendrier-scolaire.html Schools are due to be reopening in September. On August 14th, Minister of Education, Claude Meisch, “stated that the virus could be controlled within schools using appropriate measures, and emphasised the that protecting the most vulnerable should be the priority moving forward. As such, the ministry's current goal is to allow educational activities to take place with minimal restrictions.”   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823231016/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1564785.html    On September 9th, The Ministry of National Education, Children and Youth shared forecasts that “107,153 students will return to school on September 15, 2020, all levels of education combined, public and private included. This figure rises to 152,153 learners when adult education is included. In public primary and secondary education, 10,891 teachers will also return to school next week.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912132748/https://menej.gouvernement.lu/fr/support/recherche.gouvernement%2Bfr%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B09-septembre%2B09-chiffres-rentree.html    Schools are open for fall 2020 with strict health measures.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201105232540/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-en.html    On the 25th of September, The Minister of Health, and the Minister of National Education, Children and Youth, announced that the government has decided to expand the extraordinary family leave related to COVID-19, to allow parents to stay with their children outside of school hours. They also provided details on the different scenarios of the health system to fight against the spread of COVID-19 in schools. http://web.archive.org/web/20201006122016/https://men.public.lu/fr/actualites/communiques-conference-presse/2020/09/25-dispositif-cas-isole.html    Health measures for the 2020-21 school year:    To be able to contain the risk of contamination in school, the necessary health measures are being maintained:  In the classroom:  •	limited movement of pupils,  •	a fixed place for each pupil,  •	aeration and ventilation at regular intervals, with due regard for the safety of pupils (see point 3.3 of the instructions for elementary education staff and point 3.2 of the instructions for secondary education staff)  •	regular cleaning of surfaces,  •	increased hand hygiene (hand washing before start of lessons, after each break, after going to the toilet, before and after each meal)  •	social hygiene: coughing and sneezing into the crook of the elbow, avoiding physical touching (no handshaking, etc).  Within the school:  •	wearing a mask (see question below),  •	staggered breaks,  •	regular cleaning of toilets, etc,  •	fewer contacts outside the classroom,  •	organisation of movements in the school building.    Secondary schools may adopt additional measures, such as making the wearing of a mask compulsory in the classroom, or organising higher classes on an alternating basis (e.g. alternate weeks physically present in the classroom).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201018164843/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-en.html

You can organise or participate in public events with more than twenty people indoors or outdoors (cultural or sports events, congresses, etc.), provided that the following two rules apply:    People are seated in seats that have been designated for them,  Either they are two meters apart or they are wearing the mask.  Wearing a mask is compulsory for the people supervising the event and those circulating on the premises.    Compliance with these measures is also essential to enable restaurants, cafes, bars, consumer lounges and company canteens to function. If the space between the tables side by side does not allow a distance of at least 1.5 metres, they must be separated by a device such as a screen or panel.    No upper limit to how many people can take part in an event has been given, thus coded as '0'. But can be assumed that gathering size is limited to the capacity that a venue has to enact the above requirements.     http://archive.vn/2RUFn  http://archive.vn/4jnOQ

According to US embassy in Luxembourg website, previously implemented de-confinement measures before July 16th still in place: "All normal business allowed to open." https://web.archive.org/web/20200727034758/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     *Recoded from a 0 to 1 because there were safety protocols in place in workplaces e.g. masks required in restaurants while moving around

On July 16th, the government updates its coronavirus policy: "masks are mandatory for gatherings of more than 20 people in public settings if physical distance of 2m cannot be guaranteed while remaining seated. The rule does not apply to markets."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200727034758/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On July 16th, the government renewed its policy: "a key addition to the previous bills is that face masks are mandatory for gatherings of more than 20 people, both in public and private settings."   https://web.archive.org/web/20200727063952/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1550519.html

All activities are allowed with sanitary policy in place such as social distancing and wearing masks.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200727070203/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html
previous policies still remain in place   https://web.archive.org/web/20200727071336/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/coronoavirus-entreprises.html

"A laboratory test carried out on medical prescription can identify the infection. Your personal physician is in the best position to assess the value of the test in your case."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200727072037/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html

"The person who tested positive is asked to provide the Health Inspectorate with the contact details of all close contacts they have had in the days prior to the test and/or before the onset of symptoms."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200727072037/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html

On july 19th, the government of Luxembourg adopted new measures to combat the spread of the virus which includes, "no more than 10 people can gather in a private setting." https://web.archive.org/web/20200727034758/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    *Recoded from a 3 to 4 since 10 people is now included in the definition for a 4.

The government response to “When to wear a mask”: “Cultural, sports and leisure activities cannot accommodate the public if the conditions of wearing a mask and/or distancing are not respected” was changed to “Religious, cultural and sports actors are also exempted from wearing masks while carrying out their activities”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200720154130/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html (July 20th) & http://web.archive.org/web/20200721154136/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html (July 21st)

From what it seems to me, there aren't any restrictions on public events as long the audience is seated and there's >2m between seats.  "Without prejudice to Articles 2 and 3, any gathering of people bringing together more than ten people simultaneously is subject to the condition that people are assigned seats while observing a minimum distance of two meters. If the distance of two meters between the seats cannot be respected, wearing a mask is compulsory. Wearing a mask is also compulsory at all times for the supervising staff and for the participants when they are not seated."  http://web.archive.org/web/20200806150545/http://legilux.public.lu/eli/etat/leg/loi/2020/07/17/a624/consolide/20200725

"Gatherings of people at home or on the occasion of private events, in a closed place or in the open air that accommodate more than ten people are prohibited. Persons who are part of the household or who live together at home are not taken into account for the count. The ten-person limit does not apply to events organized in the establishments and places referred to in article 2 [restaurants, drinking establishments, dining rooms in accommodation establishments, consumer lounges, canteens and any other occasional dining place] where the conditions provided for in this article apply."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806150545/http://legilux.public.lu/eli/etat/leg/loi/2020/07/17/a624/consolide/20200725

“It is compulsory to cover your nose and mouth with a mask, scarf or bandana…for activities that welcome the public (shops, counters, recycling center, fairs and exhibitions, markets). Cultural, sporting and leisure activities cannot welcome the public if the conditions for wearing a mask and / or distancing are not respected.” https://web.archive.org/web/20200824155352/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr/citoyens.html
The policy that “no more than 10 people may gather in a private setting” remains in place. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823232004/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Currently, all public transport services are operating daily, mainly running at regular times. “Wearing a mask is compulsory in all circumstances in public transport, except for the driver when an interpersonal distance of two meters is respected or a separation sign separates him from the passengers.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823224415/https://www.mobiliteit.lu/fr/coronavirus-fr/

Under the FAQ on the government site, there is a question: “I am a vulnerable person, what should I do?” The response is “Stay home and respect barrier gestures” “If you must exercise an economic activity, contact your doctor by teleconsultation. In this way, you can clarify the question of whether you can continue your economic activity.” This remains the most up-to-date response to this question on the government website. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200902175028/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr/citoyens.html There is a hyperlink in this response which leads to a “Don’t have to go outside? Please stay at home! #BLEIFTDOHEEM” coronavirus information and guidelines poster set. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200902232611/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/corona_dp/FLY-Bleift-doheem.pdf
No recent policy changes found that indicate restrictions on internal movement in Luxembourg.

The ‘Covid-19 Economic Stabilisation Programme’ is still active. One objective is to “avoid redundancies by ensuring that the State takes over the remuneration of employees (permanent contracts, fixed-term contracts, apprenticeships) that are paid 80% of the salary by the employer.” Also, support measures for the cultural sector’s “self-employed professional artists, intermittent performers”: “grant additional social aid, guarantee subsidies for cancelled projects and grant short-time work benefits to employees in the sector”. Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20200818025901/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/dam-assets/dossiers/Tableau-stab-9avril-EN.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20200824141348/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/coronoavirus-entreprises.html Another goal is to “grant specific support for the year 2020 to people in low-income groups particularly affected by Covid-19, by doubling the amount of the cost of living allowance”. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200818025817/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/dam-assets/dossiers/Neistart-Letzebuerg-Tableau-Mesures.pdf

It is still current that “evictions ordered in terms of residential lease and commercial lease are suspended during the period of the state of crisis.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823225408/https://logement.public.lu/fr/support/FAQ/CoronaVirus.html Also, since March 27th, further housing assistance has been offered by The Ministry of Housing, due to potential coronavirus related income loss, including: “rent subsidy (in case of rental), the interest subsidy (in the event of home ownership)”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200824174553/https://gouvernement.lu/fr/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/03-mars/27-covid19-aides-logement.html

The government is regularly updating their website dedicated to sharing coronavirus information. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200824180152/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr.html  This is along with sharing coronavirus information on their other government websites, and on relevant government social media accounts.

It is still current that “as part of the lifting of containment, the Luxembourg government invites residents as well as border workers to participate voluntarily and free of charge in the large-scale screening test for COVID-19.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200824150552/https://guichet.public.lu/fr/citoyens/sante-social/coronavirus/depistage-covid-19.html

It is still current that upon testing positive for coronavirus, “the person who tested positive is asked to provide the Health Inspectorate with the contact details of all close contacts they have had in the days prior to the test and/or before the onset of symptoms. Afterwards, the identified people are informed that they have been in contact with a sick person.” “The Health Inspectorate officers then inquire about the state of health of the contact and inform him/her about the necessary measures and precautions, including protective measures. Based on the information obtained it is decided whether and when a COVID-19 test should be carried out.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200824144151/https://gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers.gouv_msan%2Ben%2Bdossiers%2B2020%2Bcorona-virus.html

“It is compulsory to cover your nose and mouth with a mask, scarf or bandana on public transport and for activities that welcome the public (shops, counters, recycling center, fairs and exhibitions, markets).” Exceptions include that children under 6 are not required to wear a mask. Also, “no child needs to wear a mask when participating in formal or non-formal education activities.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200824155352/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr/citoyens.html These measures were approved on July 16th. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823232004/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

“Effective August 12, 2020, third-country nationals aged 11 or over seeking to enter Luxembourg by air, whose travel does not originate from an EU member country or one of the countries exempted by the European Union (Australia, Canada, China (subject to reciprocity at European Union level), Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea from the South, Thailand, Tunisia and Uruguay), must provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test at the time of boarding. This test must have been administered less than 48 hours before the flight.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823232004/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

“Measures concerning the entry into Luxembourg of third-county nationals” were updated on the 21st August. “Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the ban on the entry of third-country nationals into the territory of Luxembourg is valid until 15 September 2020.” However, there are exceptions, including for diplomats, third-country nationals travelling for the purpose of study, and healthcare professionals, health researchers, and elderly care professionals. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200902223324/https://guichet.public.lu/en/actualites/2020/aout/11-nouvelles-mesures-entree-ressortissant-tiers.html

It remains the case that “all normal businesses are allowed to open”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902192351/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ However, strict requirements are being enforced. For example, “cinemas, theatres and cultural events are open, provided reservations are made in advance and social distancing is maintained. Bars and restaurants can open until midnight, and customers must wear a face covering on entry/exit and until seated. Social distancing of 1.5 metres must be maintained between tables.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902180417/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/luxembourg/coronavirus
No recent policy changes found regarding the cancellation of public events. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902175028/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr/citoyens.html

It is still current that “gatherings are limited to ten people” in Luxembourg. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902175655/https://luxtimes.lu/luxembourg/41592-virus-ploughs-on-as-bettel-seeks-to-extend-controls

All public transport services continue to operate daily, mainly running at regular times. Also, it remains the case that “wearing a mask is compulsory in all circumstances in public transport, except for the driver when an interpersonal distance of two meters is respected or a separation sign separates him from the passengers.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902195055/https://www.mobiliteit.lu/fr/coronavirus-fr/
No recent changes have been made to Luxembourg's income support policies. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902213718/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/coronoavirus-entreprises.html
No recent updates have been made to Luxembourg’s household financial assistance policies. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902215533/https://logement.public.lu/fr/support/FAQ/CoronaVirus.html

The government continues to regularly update their website dedicated to sharing coronavirus information. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902163900/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr.html This is along with sharing coronavirus information on their other government websites, and on relevant government social media accounts.

It is still current that “the Luxembourg government invites residents and cross-border workers to participate voluntarily in the free of charge large-scale COVID-19 testing.” “Now that PCR tests are also available for people without symptoms, more infected people can be identified and the necessary measures to prevent other people from being infected can be taken as soon as possible.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200902163116/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/en/test-covid.html
There have been no recent contact tracing policy updates in Luxembourg. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912150034/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html

“Cinemas, theatres and cultural events are open, provided reservations are made in advance and social distancing is maintained. Bars and restaurants can open until midnight, and customers must wear a face covering on entry/exit and until seated. Social distancing of 1.5 metres must be maintained between tables.   Hairdressers and beauticians are open on an appointment only basis, and cultural institutions, including libraries and museums are also open within a strict framework of reduced numbers and online reservations.  Sports halls and fitness centres are open with strict hygiene requirements and social distancing measures in place.”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912145832/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/luxembourg/coronavirus

“At public gatherings of more than 10 people, people must be assigned a seat with a distance of 2m. If the distance of 2m cannot be maintained, a mask must be worn. Wearing a mask is also compulsory for the staff and for participants, when they are not seated. (Exceptions apply e.g. to cultural and sports actors when carrying out their activities, and to persons participating in school activities. Seating is not mandatory for demonstrations, fairs, exhibitions, and markets where the public circulates).” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912150034/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html
It is still current that “no more than 10 people may gather in a private setting.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912135655/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No recent updates to “COVID-19: “Changes and measures taken in public and specific transport” in Luxembourg.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912150946/https://www.mobiliteit.lu/fr/coronavirus-fr/

The government’s response to “I am a vulnerable person, what should I do?” is still “Stay home and respect barrier gestures”. “If you must exercise an economic activity, contact your doctor by teleconsultation. In this way, you can clarify the question of whether you can continue your economic activity.” This remains the most up-to-date response to this question on the government website. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912150034/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html

“Movement Restrictions:   Is a curfew in place? No   Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912135655/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No recent international travel control policy updates. “The ban on the entry of third-country nationals into the territory of Luxembourg is valid until 15 September 2020.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912153000/https://guichet.public.lu/en/actualites/2020/aout/11-nouvelles-mesures-entree-ressortissant-tiers.html

The Luxembourg Government continues to run its Covid-19 “Recovery and solidarity fund for businesses”. “The Luxembourg Government's intention is to: encourage and maintain employment; and support businesses in those sectors hard hit by the health crisis”. “A separate application must be submitted for each month, i.e. separate applications for the months of June, July, August, September, October and November 2020.” “The undertaking receives EUR 1,250 per active employee and self-employed person (assigned to an eligible activity); the amount is EUR 250 per employee fully submitted to the short-time work regime (assigned to an eligible activity) during the month for which aid is being requested. The amount of the aid is capped at 85 % of the loss in monthly turnover.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912152000/https://guichet.public.lu/en/entreprises/financement-aides/coronavirus/fonds-relance-solidarite.html

Housing support measures remain in place for “tenants and landlords whose incomes have fallen substantially as a result of the current crisis”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912154236/https://guichet.public.lu/en/actualites/2020/mars/27-coronavirus-logement.html  The extended FACTA and CRS reporting deadline is still current; “the Luxembourg Tax Authority extended the deadline for filing FATCA and CRS returns for the 2019 reporting period from 30 June 2020 to 30 September 2020, due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912155844/https://assets.kpmg/content/dam/kpmg/us/pdf/2020/08/tnf-fatca-luxembourg-aug5-2020.pdf  Also, “any liens and mortgages that cease to be effective before 31 December 2020 are extended to 31 December 2021”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912160448/https://home.kpmg/us/en/home/insights/2020/05/tnf-luxembourg-tax-procedure-relief-measures.html

It remains the case that the Government of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg is regularly updating its websites, and social media pages, with coronavirus information. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912132947/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr.html

No recent Covid-19 testing policy update found. “The Luxembourg government invites residents and cross-border workers to participate voluntarily in the free of charge large-scale COVID-19 testing.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912145120/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/en/test-covid.html

“Masks must be worn for all activities in closed spaces, open to the public, and on public transport (except for the driver when a distance of 2m is respected or a separation panel separates him from the passengers). As of Nov.5, not able to find exact historical policy for the period of Oct. 20 to Oct. 29. But based on the RTL news (source below): private gathering limit was reduced from 10 to 4 people from Oct. 30, which implies 10 people was the limit before Oct. 30, and that aligns with the policy recorded before Oct. 20. So record this indicator as 2 "require cancelling", following coding interpretation guideline (Nov.4 version) "When private gatherings of only 10 or less are permitted (e.g. C4=4), this restriction would prevent public events from taking place, so they are recorded as required to cancel." On Friday 20 November 2020, the Luxembourg government approved a bill which provides for the establishment of new financial assistance for companies in the sectors which are most seriously affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and whose financial situation makes it difficult to bear the new burden resulting from the increase in the minimum social salary scheduled for 1 January 2021.    This assistance takes the form of a single lump sum capital grant of up to €500 per employee, whose monthly remuneration is greater than or equal to the minimum social wage and less than or equal to the qualified minimum social wage (SSM). Compensation assistance takes into account employees who were hired before 31 December 2020 and who will have been in employment during a monthly period between 1 January 2021 and 30 June 2021. This assistance is intended for sectors most affected by the health crisis, namely tourism, events, culture, hospitality, entertainment, retail trade as well as managers of continuous vocational training organisations. Coded as 3 because testing is available to much of the asymptomatic population, but asymptomatic people only have access to a free PCR test if they receive an invitation from the government. Private laboratories also offer testing, but this is not free.     The Luxembourg government is embarking on a new phase of screening with the aim to test representative samples of the population in order to monitor developments and to be as flexible as possible in the event of an increase in the number of cases. This is the best way to break infection chains and effectively trace the contacts of infected people.    The COVID-19 test at the invitation of the Luxembourg Government concerns residents and cross-border workers. It is free of charge.    The Large Scale Testing strategy divides people into representative groups, e.g. according to business sector, age and place of residence. This means that members of the same household, residents of a residential area or a circle of colleagues receive invitations deliberately staggered by several weeks according to the targeted samples. This also makes it possible to maintain continuous testing. It is therefore a strategy based on a large scale sampling approach. This organised exercise makes it possible to control and keep the rate of infections at a very low level and thus ensure the protection of everyone. The test becomes a gesture of solidarity, and protects us all.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130213106/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html

In view of the alarming growth in the number of new COVID-19 infections, the Contact Tracing Unit of the Health Inspection Department has adapted its operating procedures in order to increase its responsiveness with respect to making contact.     People who have tested positive for COVID-19 should immediately go into self-isolation, without waiting for a call from the Contact Tracing Unit.    Any person who has tested positive for COVID-19 is contacted as soon as possible by the Health Inspection; and  is assigned a reference number. While waiting for a call from the Contact Tracing Unit, the person who has tested positive can help trace and identify people with whom they have had high-risk contact.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201130213748/https://guichet.public.lu/en/citoyens/sante-social/coronavirus/tracage-contact/participation-tracage-contacts.html

The person who tested positive is asked to provide the Health Inspectorate with the contact details of all close contacts they have had in the days prior to the test or before the onset of symptoms.    Quarantine applies to people who have had high-risk contact with a person with a confirmed infection, i.e. face-to-face contact for more than 15 minutes, unprotected physical contact, etc. These people must stay at home for 7 days counting from the day of the last contact with the infected person. During the 7 days following the quarantine, they must self-monitor and wear a mask when in contact with other people. If any symptoms appear, they must immediately be tested again and placed in isolation; failure to do so incurs a fine.    Self-monitoring lasts 14 days. It applies to people who have had low-risk contact with a person who has been confirmed as being infected. People who are self-monitoring take their temperature twice a day and check that they have no respiratory problems or cough and are able to continue with their normal activities.    Link - https://web.archive.org/web/20210105162109/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/isolation-quarantine-treatment.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210105162120/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/contact-transmission.html

Anyone, regardless of nationality, aged 6 or over, wishing to travel by air to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, must present upon boarding the negative result (on paper or electronic document) of a test that detects SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid, or of a rapid antigen test, performed up to 72 hours before the flight. Policy: Restaurants, bars and cafes are closed to the public. Indeed, these places give rise to important social interactions and, by the very nature of these places dedicated to the consumption of food and / or drinks, wearing a mask is not always possible.    However, this closure does not concern school and university canteens.    Take-out, drive-through and door-to-door delivery services are also possible.    Hotels and other accommodation establishments remain open. Their restaurants and bars, however, are closed to the public, while room service and take-out service are available.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224527/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/restaurants-bars.html

Policy: In all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  for any gathering of more than 4 and up to 10 people included.  In addition to wearing a mask, a physical distance of at least 2 metres is compulsory for gatherings of more than 4 and up to 10 people included. The obligation of wearing a mask and maintaining a physical distance of at least 2 metres does not apply to people who are part of the same household or who live together.    In addition to the obligation of wearing a mask and maintaining a physical distance of at least 2 metres, the assignment of seats is compulsory for gatherings involving between 11 and 100 people included. The obligation of maintaining a physical distance of at least 2 metres does not apply to people who are part of the same household or who live together  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210330221253/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

Policy:   Given the following rules, it seems likely that public transport is widely available.  The wearing of a mask is mandatory in all circumstances in public transport, except for the driver when interpersonal distance of two meters is respected or partition panel separates passengers.    The front door of the bus remains closed . Travelers are asked to get on and off through the rear doors.    The 1st row of passenger seats should be left unoccupied whenever possible.    The driver does not sell tickets (RegioZone).    Travelers are asked to keep their distance.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html

Policy: Between 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., the movement of people on public roads is prohibited.    Exceptions to this rule: travel     with a view to their professional activity or training or education;   for medical consultations or dispensations of health care that cannot be postponed or provided at a distance;   for the purchase of medicines or health products;   for compelling family reasons, for assistance and care for vulnerable or precarious persons or for the custody of children;   responding to a judicial, police or administrative summons;    to or from a station or an airport as part of a trip abroad;   linked to transits on the motorway network;  briefs within a radius of one kilometer around the place of residence for the needs of pets;   in case of force majeure or situation of necessity.      Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html
No evidence of specific policies. Drawing from C5, it is likely that restrictions on internal movement is at strictest, recommended.

Policy: There is leniency for entry and exit for certain travellers and a ban on others, hence this is coded as a Ban. See below.  Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the European Union, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes.     Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 31 March 2021 (inclusive).    Additionally, "there is an obligation to present a negative COVID-19 test result (not older than 72 hours) before boarding any flight to Luxembourg."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183329/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

Policy: Wearing a mask is mandatory:    in all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224134/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html
Curfew also applies to the elderly.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315212440/https://covid19.public.lu/fr/mesures-sanitaires-en-vigueur/transports-publics.html

Schools are open but sanitary measures apply. Masks are required for all adults and for students from cycle 2, protective and sanitary measures must be observed, and recreation breaks or circulation of pupils must be staggered.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405111126/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-fr.html

No policy change. Businesses are allowed to open but must comply with sanitary measures and limits on store capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183059/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html

No policy change. Restrictions on public gatherings apply. Performance venues will be able to accommodate up to 100 spectators wearing masks, provided that they are assigned a seat and maintain an interpersonal distance of 2 metres if they do not belong to the same household or cohabit.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405102359/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/sport-religion-culture.html

No policy change. Any gathering exceeding 100 people is prohibited. Any gathering of more than 4 and up to and including 10 people is subject to the condition that the people wear masks and observe a minimum distance of 2 metres. Any gatherings involving between 11 and 100 people included is subject to the condition that the persons wear masks and are assigned seats by observing a minimum distance of 2 metres. Private gatherings are limited to people of the same household and up to maximum of 2 visitors who are also part of a same household.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405102126/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

No policy change. Public transport open with sanitary measures in place. Masks are compulsory, passengers must enter from the back of the bus and maintain social distancing, the first row of seats must remained unoccupied, and transport drivers are unable to sell tickets.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405101517/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html
No policy change. Curfew in place from 11pm to 6am.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210317182134/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html
No restrictions, but it is recommended to limit travel as much as possible.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405104700/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

No policy change. Businesses, including non-essential shops, are open and must observe existing sanitary measures. A limit of one customer per 10m2 applies to all shops open to the public regardless of their sales area. However, small shops with a sales area of less than 20m2 can accommodate a maximum of two customers at the same time. Shopping centres with a sales area equal to or greater than 400m2 must in addition, provide a health protocol, which has be accepted by the National Health Directorate. Restaurants, cafes, and bars are similarly allowed to open but must comply with restrictions on opening hours and capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208224155/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html    Temporary health recommendations from the Department of Health for businesses/workplaces:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227103211/https://sante.public.lu/fr/espace-professionnel/recommandations/direction-sante/000-covid-19/recommandations-sanitaires-temporaires/index.html

No policy change. Both indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted, but must not exceed 100 people. Masks and social distancing are required for gatherings of more than 4 people. Private gatherings are limited to people of the same household and a maximum of two additional visitors from the same household. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area as well as the citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican / Holy See, are free to enter the territory of the Great Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to reach their home. No policy change. Tests available at several locations with a prescription. If you are not presenting COVID-19 symptoms and do not possess a medical prescription, laboratories offer COVID-19 tests at your own expense. Testing also available via the Large Scale Testing program. Large Scale Testing allows for residents and cross border workers to get tested either by a PCR test (oral swab) or a serological test (blood sample). An invitation is sent either via post or e-mail with a personalized code, allowing for everyone to take part free of charge.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210302163205/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html

Vaccines available to adults 55 and older, starting with the oldest, as well as people that may be at increased risk due to a pre-existing health condition. The Education Minister announced that students will begin using self-administered rapid tests upon their return from Easter break. Each of Luxembourg’s 120,000 students and school staff will receive one such test per week.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210416171239/https://www.luxtimes.lu/en/luxembourg/government-meets-to-decide-about-restrictions-expiring-next-week-607856adde135b9236207033

No policy change. The Chamber of Deputies of Luxembourg extended the Covid-19 restrictions in place until May 15, after expiring on April 25th.   Sanitary measures such as mandatory mask-wearing, reduced contact with other student groups, and staggered recreation breaks still apply.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070134/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-fr.html     http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780

No policy change. All shops, including non-essential ones, are open to the public with sanitary measures in place. Businesses are still subject to capacity limitations depending on their size. Bill7802 passed by the Chamber of Deputies clarifies that a terrace is "an outdoor space and in the open air, open on at least three surfaces in order to allow the free circulation of air. and the natural ventilation of the space".     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426071821/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426072024/https://sante.public.lu/fr/espace-professionnel/recommandations/direction-sante/000-covid-19/recommandations-sanitaires-temporaires/index.html

Bill7802 provides some relaxation for musical and sports activities. Up to 10 people are allowed to come together to practice musical activities if they are seated and respect the two-meter distance between them. For sports, the required area for activity is now 10m2, and sports practice is allowed for groups of +2 people as long as they can keep a cautionary distance of two meters.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426070741/https://www.chd.lu/wps/portal/public/Accueil/Actualite/ALaUne/?current=true&urile=wcm%3Apath%3Aactualite.public.chd.lu%2FST-www.chd.lu%2Fsa-actualites%2F813d8533-fb09-4878-b42d-1a5cff083780    http://web.archive.org/web/20210426073541/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/sport-religion-culture.html

All indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted if protective measures are applied. No more than 100 people can participate in these meetings, children included. Masks are still mandatory in all activities open to the public that happen in closed spaces such as shops or supermarkets. There are no policy changes regarding private gatherings, which are restricted to members of the same household or a maximum of 2 visitors, these having to abide by safety measures.     Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074623/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

No policy change. Wearing a mask is compulsory in public transportation, and some seats are left unoccupied.     Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426074740/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426081808/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/get-tested.html

No policy change. There are several protective measures in place when using public transportation. Mask is compulsory, social distance must be respected, and some seats will remain unoccupied.    Links:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210508092939/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

No policy change. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508093420/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

No policy change. Tests are widely available among the population in Luxembourg, especially through the Large Scale Testing (LST). This program was put into place not only to monitor the spread of the virus across the country, but also to allow flexibility and foresight when there is an increase in cases. This allows to break infection chains and to keep the infection rate low. Large Scale Testing allows for residents and cross border workers to get tested either by a PCR test (oral swab) or a serological DBS test ("Dry Blood Spot"). An invitation is sent either via post or e-mail with a personalized code, allowing for everyone to take part free of charge.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508093846/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/get-tested.html

In Luxembourg, vaccine availability is universal. People over 16 years old are eligible to register for the vaccine waiting list, although priority will be given to the oldest people. Residents aged between 30 and 54 have the opportunity to register online to get the Vaxzevria (Astrazeneca) vaccine. According to Prime Minister Xavier Bettel, more than 31.000 people have already registered for this waitlist.     Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508095540/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210508095738/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519

Bars and restaurants can now open until 10 pm rather than 6 pm. These establishments can now host diners indoors again, though they will have to undergo a rapid test before entering. Up to 4 people can now sit at the same table. Protective measures such as social distance and mask-wearing when not seated still apply.     Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100731/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100958/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/restaurants-bars.html

Up to 150 people are allowed to attend events. Mask-wearing and respecting a minimum distance of 2 meters are mandatory. Gatherings of more than 150 people are only permitted under stricter prevention conditions and with the special dispensation of the health authorities.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517101836/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100731/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519

No policy change. All public transportation functions as normal with some protective measures in place.  Social distancing and mask-wearing are mandatory in all public transport.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517102025/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

The nightly curfew has now been pushed from 11 pm to midnight to accommodate the changes in restaurants and bar openings. Thus, a curfew remains in place from midnight to 6 am.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517102352/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html

Additional sanitary measures apply to travelers coming from India. "Until 30 June 2021, any person (regardless of nationality and age) who stayed in India during the 14 days prior to his or her arrival on Luxembourg territory must undergo a nucleic acid amplification test of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA - PCR (polymerase chain reaction), TMA (transcription-mediated amplification) or LAMP (loop-mediated isothermal amplification) - upon arrival in the Grand Duchy, and inform the medical analysis laboratory that he or she has stayed in India. This obligation applies to any person who has stayed in India during the 14 days preceding his/her arrival, regardless of the duration of the stay in India and in Luxembourg, and regardless of the means of transport to the Grand Duchy."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210516024315/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

No policy change.  Weekly updates on governmental mitigation efforts, policy changes, and the evolution of the virus can be found on governmental sources.     Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210517103315/https://covid19.public.lu/en.html

The Government of Luxembourg and the country's health authorities are leading the vaccination efforts in Luxembourg. According to governmental sources, approximately 7.500 vaccines are injected per day, and more than 277.000 vaccines have already been administered. Luxembourg is now in Phase 6 of its vaccination process. General residents between 16 and 54 years old, starting by the oldest, are being vaccinated.    Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517104111/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

From 17 May, lateral flow tests will be available in pharmacies. "A positive result is immediately reported by the health professional to the Health Directorate to ensure the follow-up of the patient and initiate contact tracing. The cost of the test is charged to the person wishing to be tested."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210512161428/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2021/05-mai/12-tests-rapides-pharmacies.html

Four in ten adults in Luxembourg have now had at least one vaccine dose. More than 200.000 people in Luxembourg have had at least one dose of the vaccine. Governmental sources indicate that Luxembourg is currently in phase 6 of the vaccination process. General resident population between 16 and 54 years (starting with the oldest) are eligible to get the vaccine. Residents aged between 30 and 54 have the opportunity to register online on a waiting list to express their interest in being voluntarily vaccinated against COVID-19 with the Vaxzevria vaccine (AstraZeneca). More than 340.000 doses have been administered in Luxembourg. Of these, approximately 226.000 are first doses, and 113.353 are second doses. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 June 2021 (inclusive). Exempt from this rule are nationals from Australia, China, Hong Kong, Macao, New Zealand, Ruanda, Thailand, South Korea, and Singapore.    New constraints have been implemented for travelers coming from the United Kingdom to Luxembourg. These individuals will be subject to a free-of-charge test on arrival, a strict quarantine of seven days, and a later second test. No policy change. Tests are widely available among the population in Luxembourg, especially through the Large Scale Testing (LST). This program was put into place not only to monitor the spread of the virus across the country but also to allow flexibility and foresight when there is an increase in cases. This allows to break infection chains and to keep the infection rate low. Large Scale Testing allows for residents and cross border workers to get tested either by a PCR test (oral swab) or a serological DBS test ("Dry Blood Spot"). An invitation is sent either via post or e-mail with a personalized code, allowing for everyone to take part free of charge.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210607131302/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/get-tested.html
No policy change. Contact tracing forms are available on governmental sources.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210426222132/https://covid19.public.lu/en/contact-tracing.html

Governmental sources indicate that Luxembourg is currently in phase 6 of the vaccination process. General resident population between 16 and 54 years (starting with the oldest) are eligible to get the vaccine. Residents aged between 30 and 54 have the opportunity to register online on a waiting list to express their interest in being voluntarily vaccinated against COVID-19 with the Vaxzevria vaccine (AstraZeneca). Approximately 8.500 doses are administered every day in Luxembourg.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210607131819/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

No policy change. Shops, including non-essential shops, are open to all public. Various protective measures accompany this opening. A limit of one customer per 10m2 applies to all shops. However, small shops with a sales area of less than 20m2 can accommodate a maximum of two customers at the same time. Shopping centers with a sales area equal to or greater than 400m2 must, in addition, provide a health protocol, which has to be accepted by the National Health Directorate. Restaurants, bars, and cafés are open to the public from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., both indoors and outdoors. However, some measures must be respected. For example, there's a  maximum of 4 people per table unless these are from the same household. Other restrictions, such as mask-wearing for those not seated at the table or keeping a distance of 1.5 meters between tables apply.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210610160500/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210610160519/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/restaurants-bars.html

No policy change. Up to 150 people are allowed to attend events. Mask-wearing and respecting a minimum distance of 2 meters are mandatory. Gatherings of more than 150 people are only permitted under stricter prevention conditions and with the special dispensation of the health authorities.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210610160715/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

Governmental sources indicate that Luxembourg is currently in phase 6 of the vaccination process. General resident population between 16 and 54 years (starting with the oldest) are eligible to get the vaccine. Residents aged between 30 and 54 have the opportunity to register online on a waiting list to express their interest in being voluntarily vaccinated against COVID-19 with the Vaxzevria vaccine (AstraZeneca). Residents aged 18 years and older have the opportunity to register online on 2 separate waiting lists to express their interest in being voluntarily vaccinated against COVID-19 with the Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca) or Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccine. Approximately 423.029 have been administered in Luxembourg.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210610162124/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

Restaurants, bars, and cafés are open to the public both indoors and outdoors.  The accommodation of customers is subject to specific rules depending on the system under which these establishments choose to operate. Owners of restaurants, bars, and cafés can choose whether they want to opt for the CovidCheck system or not. The CovidCheck system is a system applicable to establishments (e.g. restaurants, bars, fitness centres, shops, etc.), events or gatherings (e.g. sporting events, concerts, etc.) open to the public, where entry is reserved exclusively for people (customers, spectators, staff, supervisors) who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative (either by means of an on-site self-test or by means of a certified negative result). Children under 6 years of age are exempt from performing an on-site self-test or presenting a COVID-19 test certificate. For those establishments that require CovidCheck, they operate without having to comply with special sanitary measures such as wearing a mask for staff in direct contact with customers or for customers themselves, and customers are no longer obliged to eat at the table and to respect the distance between tables. For those who decide not to opt for requiring CovidCheck, some protective measures such as mask-wearing and social distance are required.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620081548/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/restaurants-bars.html

Both indoor and outdoor gatherings are permitted. However, it is still recommended to limit interpersonal contacts and travel and to continue to respect the protective measures. These include wearing a mask, avoiding handshaking or kissing, and social distancing.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620081756/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

Any gathering exceeding 300 people is prohibited.    Any gathering of 11 and up to and including 50 people is subject to the condition that the people wear masks and observe a minimum distance of 2 metres.    Gatherings of 11 and up to 300 people can be held under the CovidCheck system. In this case, the requirement to wear a mask, the requirement for a minimum physical distance of 2 metres and the requirement for seating arrangements do not apply.    Certain events may gather more than 300 people without exceeding the maximum limit of 2,000 people, provided that they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate, which defines the health measures that must be observed.    Link.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620081756/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

No policy change. Public transportation in Luxembourg functions as normal, with protective measures applied. Wearing a mask is compulsory on all public transport, and various seats must be left unoccupied to keep a distance of two meters.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210610160857/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/public-transport.html

The curfew has been lifted. People can now circulate in public at nighttime. However, there are various restrictions that pose limits to quotidian activities such as gatherings or shopping.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620082647/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html

Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 September 2021 (inclusive).    "For any person authorised to enter Luxembourg (regardless of nationality), it is compulsory to present, before boarding a flight to Luxembourg    either a vaccination certificate attesting to a complete vaccination pattern (see FAQ) carried out with a vaccine that has been authorised for use by the European Medicines Agency, i.e. the vaccines of the companies AstraZeneca, BioNTech/Pfizer, Johnson&Johnson and Moderna, issued by a public or medical authority of a Member State of the European Union or of a Member State of the Schengen Area.  Another option is to present a recovery certificate issued by a practitioner or national authority of an EU Member State or Schengen Area Member State for persons who have had a recent SARS-CoV-2 infection within 6 months prior to travel and who have completed the applicable isolation period in the respective country with resolution of all symptoms of infection.  Finally, the traveler could also present the negative result (on paper or electronically) of a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA (PCR, TMA or LAMP methods) carried out less than 72 hours before the flight or of a SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen test carried out less than 48 hours before the flight, by a medical analysis laboratory or any other entity authorised for this purpose. The negative result of the test must be presented, if necessary accompanied by a translation, in one of the administrative languages of Luxembourg or in English, Italian, Spanish or Portuguese.  This applies to all departures to Luxembourg, including those from Member States of the European Union or the Schengen area.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210618185552/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

Link:    http://web.archive.org/web/20210716083637/https://www.luxtimes.lu/en/luxembourg/covid-law-luxembourg-adopts-new-covid-rules-for-summer-break-60f00bfdde135b9236376c01
No policy change. There are no restrictions on internal movement.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620082647/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html  Link:

No policy change with respect to travel restrictions. Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 September 2021 (inclusive).    "For any person (aged 12 or older) authorised to enter Luxembourg (regardless of nationality), it is compulsory to present, before boarding a flight to Luxembourg.    -either a vaccination certificate attesting to a complete vaccination pattern (see FAQ) carried out with a vaccine that has been authorised for use by the European Medicines Agency, i.e. the vaccines of the companies AstraZeneca, BioNTech/Pfizer, Johnson&Johnson and Moderna, issued by a public or medical authority of a Member State of the European Union or of a Member State of the Schengen Area.  Another option is to present a recovery certificate issued by a practitioner or national authority of an EU Member State or Schengen Area Member State for persons who have had a recent SARS-CoV-2 infection within 6 months prior to travel and who have completed the applicable isolation period in the respective country with resolution of all symptoms of infection.  Finally, the traveler could also present the negative result (on paper or electronically) of a nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA (PCR, TMA or LAMP methods) carried out less than 72 hours before the flight or of a SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen test carried out less than 48 hours before the flight, by a medical analysis laboratory or any other entity authorised for this purpose. The negative result of the test must be presented, if necessary accompanied by a translation, in one of the administrative languages of Luxembourg or in English, Italian, Spanish or Portuguese.  This applies to all departures to Luxembourg, including those from Member States of the European Union or the Schengen area.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210716084636/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

No policy change. Weekly updates on governmental mitigation efforts, policy changes, and the evolution of the virus can be found on governmental sources.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210714151939/https://covid19.public.lu/en.html

Testing is generally available in Luxembourg, especially thanks to the Large Scale Testing. Citizens can access a test by invitation or demand: "Any resident with a national identification number who is currently living in Luxembourg can make an appointment for a free COVID-19 PCR test in any LST drive-in station at their own convenience.      Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210708081758/https://delano.lu/article/free-large-scale-testing-goes-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210708081735/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html
No policy change. Contact tracing forms are available on governmental sources.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210708081939/https://covid19.public.lu/en/contact-tracing.html

No policy change. Facial coverings are required in some public spaces. However, in some of these shops, restaurants, or public posts, the CovidCheck certificate exempts certain people from these measures.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210708075411/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/restaurants-bars.html

Governmental sources indicate that Luxembourg is currently in phase 6 of the vaccination process. Anyone who is 18 and above (12 and above for messenger RNA vaccines) have the opportunity, under certain conditions, to register online on one of the waiting lists and express their interest in being voluntarily vaccinated against COVID-19. Anyone aged 18 or older can register to be vaccinated with Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca), Janssen (J&J), or an mRNA vaccine (Pfizer or Moderna).  People between 12 and 17 can register to get the Pfizer vaccine. As of today, more than 633,000 vaccines have been administered in the country.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210716085541/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html

Governmental sources state that vulnerable people should "stay at home and respect the protective measures". They also indicate that if a vulnerable person "absolutely has to go out", several measures should be respected. Shopping outside of peak hours and avoiding public transport are two examples of these recommendations.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210716090053/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/vulnerable-persons.html
Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210814161748/https://men.public.lu/en/support/coronavirus/faq-en.html

Shops and businesses, including non-essential ones, are allowed to open. Shopping centers with a sales area equal to or greater than 400m2 must provide a health protocol, which has be accepted by the National Health Directorate.    Restaurants, bars, and cafes are allowed to open for both indoor and outdoor service. The accommodation of customers is subject to specific rules depending on if the establishment chooses to operate using the CovidCheck system. The CovidCheck system is a system applicable to private persons and private or public establishments (e.g. restaurants, bars, fitness centres, shops, etc.) or events (e.g. sporting events, concerts, etc.) open to the public, where entry is reserved exclusively for people (customers, guests, spectators, staff, supervisors) who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative (either by means of an on-site self-test or by means of a certified negative result).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210814155754/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html

Some public events allowed if current restrictions on gatherings are observed. Gatherings of 11 and up to 300 people can be held, with prior notification, under the CovidCheck system. In this case, the requirement to wear a mask, the requirement for a minimum physical distance of 2 metres and the requirement for seating arrangements do not apply. Certain events may gather more than 300 people without exceeding the maximum limit of 2,000 people, provided that they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate, which defines the health measures that must be observed.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210814155519/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814155754/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html

Private gatherings: For private parties of up to 10 guests, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed. For 11 or more people, masks must be worn and a distance of 2 metres between people must be observed. And for 51 or more people, the obligation of assigned seats applies.    Public gatherings: Any public gathering of more than 300 people is prohibited. Any gathering of 11 and up to and including 50 people is subject to the condition that the people wear masks and observe a minimum distance of 2 metres. Gatherings of 11 and up to 300 people can be held, with prior notification, under the CovidCheck system*. In this case, the requirement to wear a mask, the requirement for a minimum physical distance of 2 metres and the requirement for seating arrangements do not apply. Certain events may gather more than 300 people without exceeding the maximum limit of 2,000 people, provided that they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate, which defines the health measures that must be observed.    *The CovidCheck system is a system applicable to private persons and private or public establishments (e.g. restaurants, bars, fitness centres, shops, etc.) or events (e.g. sporting events, concerts, etc.) open to the public, where entry is reserved exclusively for people (customers, guests, spectators, staff, supervisors) who have been vaccinated, recovered or tested negative (either by means of an on-site self-test or by means of a certified negative result).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210814155519/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814155754/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html

Citizens of the European Union and of the countries associated with the Schengen area, as well as citizens of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Saint See, are free to enter Luxembourg, regardless of the purpose of the stay and not only to return to their homes. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 30 September 2021, except those from approved countries (see link for complete list).    Travelers 12 years and older must present evidence of full vaccination, proof of recovery from Covid-19 up to 6 months prior to travel, or a SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA (PCR, TMA or LAMP methods) carried out less than 72 hours before the flight or of a SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen test carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.    Additional sanitary measures are applicable until 14 September 2021 for India, regardless of the means of transport.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210814160933/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

If you have received a prescription from a medical professional, you can book an appointment at available laboratories. If you are not presenting COVID-19 symptoms and do not possess a medical prescription, laboratories offer COVID-19 tests at your own expense. Residents of Luxembourg may be invited via email or post to take a test or can request an appointment for a free COVID-19 PCR test in any LST drive-in station. Gatherings exceeding 300 people are prohibited, unless they are pre-authorised using the CovidCheck system. Gatherings exceeding 300 people are prohibited, unless they are pre-authorised using the CovidCheck system or Health Directorate. For private gatherings of up to 10 people, no restrictions or health measures are required. For gatherings for 11+ people, masks and social distancing are required. For 51+ people, assigned seats are required. Gatherings of 11+ to 300 people can take place with prior permission using the CovidCheck system, in which case sanitary measures no longer apply. For public gatherings of 300-2000 people, the Health Directorate must be notified in advance and will determine the appropriate health protocol.  Recommendations are still to limit interpersonal contact.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210814155519/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html

Face masks are compulsory on public transport, except the driver if social distancing feasible or a barrier is in place.
